div.p: Greetings. I received your letter today, reverend father, for the first time; however, I fear that our merchants have already departed, and therefore I am writing this before I have read the letter of Mr. Peter Martyr.

We will have certain news about the Venetians at our fair; Mr. Friedrich von Salis is also expected, who was with me in Ilanz and promised to write himself; he instructed me to commend him to you very much; however, I forgot to do so amidst the great turmoil of affairs. Nevertheless, I have faithfully communicated all your matters that needed to be shared.
I will send back the rest of your items in 8 days, if I live; for now, there is nothing new; I am attaching a note for you to read.

The man from Sax has traveled through here, intending to obtain service with the Venetians; however, he doubts it; he will be here again in 8 or 10 days; then he will communicate everything. Farewell, reverend father in Christ.
Chur, on St. Martin's Day, in the year 1561.
To the most distinguished man, excellent in learning and piety, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, most vigilant overseer of the Church of Zurich, his ever-honorable lord and patron.
